urn:contentItem:5X0R-7YV1-JCBW-N508-00000-00Big tech's day in court: the people v Silicon Valley giants;Google is about to be to investigated for anti-competitive practices, reports Danny Fortson in San Francisco2019-09-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:13ZLexisNexisBUSINESS AND MONEY;NEWSPg. 7Big tech's day in court: the people v Silicon Valley giantsGoogle is about to be to investigated for anti-competitive practices, reports Danny Fortson in San FranciscoDanny Fortson

Just over 21 years ago, American regulators launched a landmark competition case against Microsoft. The lawsuit tied the software giant up in knots for years and opened the way for upstarts, including a little search engine called Google.

On the steps of the US Supreme Court tomorrow, Google will get its turn. Ken Paxton, attorney-general of Texas, will announce a sweeping investigation - involving up to 40 other states - into whether the $840bn (£684bn) global tech behemoth is unlawfully squashing competitors and hurting consumers, setting the stage for the most important antitrust case of this century.

The action could have farreaching effects on how powerful technologies, from facial recognition to artificial intelligence, are developed, and by whom. The move follows separate inquiries launched by the Department of Justice and the US House of Representatives into the wealth, power and policies of the tech giants Apple, Google, Facebook and Amazon.

The crackdowns mark an astonishing about-turn from even two years ago, when Silicon Valley was untroubled by government oversight. In the wake of data breaches, disinformation scandals, hefty fines over privacy violations and the targeting of children online, breaking up America's biggest tech firms has become a key plank of several Democratic presidential campaigns, notably Elizabeth Warren's.

Targeting the industry has become that rare beast for America's bitterly divided political class - common ground. The attorneysgeneral behind the impending investigation are Republican and Democrat.

Facebook is also feeling the heat. The attorney-general of New York, Letitia James, announced a "bipartisan coalition" on Friday, including seven other states and the District of Columbia, to investigate the social media giant. She said: "Even the largest social media platform in the world must follow the law and respect consumers."

The investigation will examine whether Facebook, which snaps up rivals that threaten its dominance, has stifled competition. The Federal Trade Commission fined the social media company a record $5bn in July over data privacy failings related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

In response to the Google investigation, Kent Walker, the company's chief legal officer, penned a blog post titled "Google's services create choice for consumers, and spur innovation in the US", in which he pledged to work with investigators: "We look forward to showing how we are investing in innovation, providing services that people want, and engaging in robust and fair competition."

The company has barely had time to catch its breath from its last run-in with the law, which concluded on Wednesday. Google's sister company, YouTube, agreed to pay $170m to settle charges brought by James and others that the site illegally collected data on children in order to target them with ads.

James said: "Google and YouTube knowingly and illegally monitored, tracked, and served targeted ads to young children just to keep advertising dollars rolling in. These companies put children at risk and abused their power, which is why we are imposing major reforms."

The state and federal inquiries are expected to be sweeping, encompassing everything from how the likes of Google and Facebook treat personal data to how their services compete with, and often suffocate, those of rivals. Google has been accused of prioritising its own services in search results.

The industry's pursuit of children is expected to draw extra scrutiny. After last week's fine, YouTube boss Susan Wojcicki wrote: "Nothing is more important than protecting kids and their privacy, " and insisted that the platform was changing its ways. That same day, YouTube was sued again. For what? "Deceptive" campaigns directed at kids and "rampant" violations of privacy laws.

Microsoft resolved the final remnants of its antitrust case last year, decades after it began. Today it is the most valuable company in the West, worth more than $1 trillion.

As Google, Facebook and others gird themselves for the fight of their lives, they will no doubt be studying how their old rival went into the fire, and survived.

urn:contentItem:60GG-C6Y1-DY1R-B17Y-00000-00Big techs defend themselves against Congress2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:13ZLexisNexisBig techs defend themselves against Congress


Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple are targeted for their enormous power in the market and for potential abuses of competition.
Although in Europe and Asia they had to take fines and change their policy, until now Washington had not bothered to regulate its operations.


The situation had some of what was seen in the 1990s, when the big tobacco companies or Microsoft were whites of the U.S. government.
But this time, the ones who had to appear on a House committee of Congress were the ceos of delegates of the country's four largest technology, Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple, targeted by the authorities for their market power and potential abuses of competition. These four giants dominate every aspect of digital life, from e-commerce to the digital identity of most internet users. In Europe and Asia they faced hefty fines or changed their policies when it came to operations, but the United States, until now, had not been concerned about the size of its operations.
Through videoconferencing, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai defended their companies by noting that they stand up for American values, that they did not start out as large companies and still have significant competition today.
"We compete against all the companies that appear in this event, as well as many others that sell ads and connect people," Zuckerberg said.
"We believe in the values — democracy, competence, inclusion and freedom of expression – in which the American economy is based. Many other tech companies share these values, but there is no guarantee that ours will win. For example, China is building its own version of the internet focused on very different ideas and they are exporting that vision to other countries," warned the founder of the world's leading social network.
Zuckerberg also said that, despite its acquisition of WhatsApp and Instagram, it still has competition. In addition, it underlined the benefits of these companies being part of a larger company, which allowed them to make technological advances that favored the population.
This same idea is shared by Amazon. Its founder, Jeff Bezos, recalled that he started "in a garage" and that he only achieved his current size thanks to his continued focus on the consumer. "There are things small businesses simply can't do. I don't care how good an entrepreneur you are, you're not going to build a carbon fiber Boeing 787 in your garage," he said. Unlike the other three, this was his first intervention in Congress. "I think Amazon should be subject to scrutiny. We should scrutinize all the major institutions, whether it's companies, government agencies or NGOs," Bezos concluded.
On his side, Sundar Pichai, the CEO of Alphabet, Google's parent company, defended the benefits to the population of the free services offered by his company. And he gave as an example the benefits he brought for his own life, as he grew up in India without internet access.
Related contentTurkey passes new law to control social media
"We are committed to working with congressmen to protect consumers, maintain America's technological role in the world, and ensure that all Americans have access to the incredible opportunities that technology creates," Pichai said.
Apple CEO Tim Cook defended his company's role as an intermediary in the app market by rejecting allegations thatfees that you charge companies for their app are abusive. To demonstrate this, he said the commissions paid are now lower than before the Apple app store existed, as well as that he never raised the percentage he charges.
"The App Store evolves with the times and every change was in the direction of providing a better experience for our users and an attractive business opportunity for our developers," Cook said.
Trump threat: Calls for concrete action
"There was a lot of chatty and little action for years," he said.
Without any disguise on his stance, U.S. President Donald Trump threatened tech. "If Congress doesn't bring justice to the big tech, something I should have done years ago, I'll do it with an executive order," he said on Twitter. The representative criticized that "there has been a lot of chitchat and little action in Washington for years," stating that American citizens are already "tired." The tycoon accuses the country's great technology of having a Democratic bias.

urn:contentItem:5TH8-PG11-DY4X-T18Y-00000-00Big Tech's Dependence on Data Confounds Antitrust Effort2018-10-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:13ZLexisNexisBig Tech's Dependence on Data Confounds Antitrust EffortBrendan Bordelon

Federal antitrust regulators are scrambling to catch up to the competitive changes wrought by the reams of consumer data collected and collated by Facebook, Google, and other top tech platforms.

That s the message hammered home throughout a series of discussions convened by the Federal Trade Commission on the future of competition policy in the 21st century. As one of the nation s premier antitrust enforcers, the FTC prides itself on its ability to protect consumers against collusion and predatory pricing from brick-and-mortar establishments that corner too much of the marketplace.

But when it comes to enforcing competition rules against the world s dominant tech platforms many of which have amassed tremendous wealth and power, in part by providing consumers with free services in exchange for advertising revenue and access to user data the commissioners admit they re out of their depth.

These [digital] marketplaces may not operate like they did in history, or how we learned about them in economics textbooks, said Rohit Chopra, one of two Democratic FTC commissioners, at an antitrust hearing convened by the commission Monday. And if we do not understand them, we are in big trouble.

The commission s other Democrat agrees. In a speech late last month, Rebecca Kelly Slaughter stressed that technological changes required a critical rethinking of the FTC s antitrust doctrine.

The notion has bipartisan buy-in. While not going quite as far as his colleagues, Republican FTC Chairman Joseph Simons told senators earlier this month that the traditional consumer welfare model of antitrust where an uptick in the dollar amount paid by consumers acts as the primary driver of antitrust actions is likely in need of an update.

One of the things where we could probably use some help, and new developments in the consumer-welfare model, would be how to deal with just these markets you re describing, where the product is essentially given away for free, Simons told Sen. Mike Lee during an oversight hearing.

As the commission continues its listening tour, which is set to conclude in November, the key question for both industry and consumer advocates is just how expansive Simons s new developments in antitrust doctrine will be. The tech industry and many economists believe that while tinkering on the margins is fine, upending the current model of antitrust enforcement to accomplish political or societal goals means the rules could be applied arbitrarily and in a way that reduces innovation by undermining regulatory certainty.

I think it would be a remarkable mistake to open the Pandora s box for the antitrust tools to cover all sorts of things, said Marianela López-Galdos, the head of competition and regulatory policy at the Computer & Communications Industry Association, which includes Facebook, Google, and Amazon as members.

Others argue that the FTC s mandate to protect consumers particularly on issues of data privacy requires the commission to rethink the consumer-welfare model of antitrust. If nothing else, they hope to thread the needle by setting a real-world price on the consumer data being collected by platforms that offer their products for free.

I actually think within the context of current antitrust law, the cases of Facebook, Google in particular will fit once we have a good understanding of data as a currency, said Roger McNamee, the founder of venture-capital firm Elevation Partners. They just gave a Nobel Prize this week to people who figured out how to [price] carbon. So I m not actually talking about a novel theory any longer.

McNamee believes that the FTC should bring antitrust enforcement cases against both Google and Facebook.

Most economists are skeptical of any drastic changes to antitrust enforcement when it comes to the major tech platforms. In order to get around the thorny problem of pricing a free service, they ve focused on ways to identify the ease and prevalence of multi-homing where consumers use multiple platforms simultaneously or for similar purposes, such as the dual use of ride-hairing apps Uber and Lyft.

We re really good at analyzing things that have positive dollar prices attached to them, said David Evans, an economist at the University of Chicago Law School. And we re not so good at valuing the services themselves, independent of the prices. And what s going to need to happen is there s going to have to be a greater investment of effort in dealing with the non-price dimension of these platforms in order to really do sensible analyses.

But while McNamee is still hoping to find a way to put a dollar amount on consumer data and plug it into the current antitrust model, he says a focus on empirical metrics won t be enough to tackle big tech s phenomenal power and reach.

These issues, at the scale these companies operate at, cannot be viewed as only about markets and only about economics, said McNamee. Facebook operates 2.2 billion Truman Shows, and between Facebook and Google and the use of filter bubbles they have changed the public square really dramatically. So their form of market power has implications that we ve never seen previously.

Most economists reject that notion, arguing that the scale of Facebook, Google, and Amazon could produce tremendous benefits for consumers. Shoehorning social or political objectives into antitrust policy, they say, would hurt both consumers and the companies.

The antitrust statutes are competition statutes, said Michael Salinger, an economist at Boston University. So if you want to have policies that are based on something other than competition, then you need to pass other laws.

The FTC hearings on antitrust come as Washington wrestles with the continued fallout from Big Tech s role in foreign election interference and a slew of data privacy scandals. The Trump administration is also currently weighing antitrust remedies to correct perceived anti-conservative biases at Facebook and Google, and the president himself recently suggested that both companies, as well as Amazon, may be in a very antitrust situation.

That activity likely weighs on the minds of the FTC commissioners and staff as they conduct their review. I would be surprised if they re not a little bit influenced by the current political environment, said Steven Tadelis, an economist at the University of California, Berkeley.

But most observers are confident that however the FTC chooses to tackle the problem of antitrust enforcement in a data-driven, platform-dominated world, it will make its decision independently.

They re basically professionals who are applying tools to figure out whether people are violating the antitrust laws, said Evans. And I think they tune out all the political talk in the background.

urn:contentItem:5XR1-1DK1-DYTY-C04C-00000-00"BIG TECH'S DIRTY LITTLE SECRET;Facebook and YouTube are full of disturbing videos of violence and racism. Should the government make plans to regulate social media, asks Mark Tighe2018-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:13ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15"BIG TECH'S DIRTY LITTLE SECRETFacebook and YouTube are full of disturbing videos of violence and racism. Should the government make plans to regulate social media, asks Mark TigheMark Tighe

Andy Way, a professor of computing at Dublin City University, had been on Facebook for six years when he decided to quit. In early 2015 he reported a video to Facebook that showed bestiality, concerned that the platform's algorithms might recommend it to his daughter. The response he got from Facebook was that the content did not contravene its community standards. Annoyed, Way told Facebook they had just lost a user.

Similar stories were shared by other people who had reported offensive content in the aftermath of a Channel 4 Dispatches exposé on Facebook's moderation practices last week. It showed an undercover reporter working at CPL in Dublin alongside some 650 moderators reviewing content flagged by Facebook's users. The reporter found staff were instructed to ignore or "mark as disturbing" much offensive content.

New staff were shown a woman holding her young daughter's head under water in a bath because her "first crush is a negro boy". They were told this was not hate speech and should be "ignored".

Recruits were also told to "ignore" evidence that users were under 13 unless they explicitly admitted this. Staff were also instructed to allow videos that showed the "kicking, beating or slapping of a child or an animal by an adult", "the inflicting of a burn or a cut wound by an adult" or "the tossing, rotating or shaking of an infant too young to stand by their wrists, ankles, legs, arms or neck".

By way of example, trainers showed a distressing video showing a two-year-old boy being physically beaten by a man. Moderators were told to mark these videos as "disturbing", meaning they remained accessible to those over 18.

The undercover reporter was told by other moderators that some pages were "shielded", such as one for the far-right group Britain First as it had more than 2m followers. Having more than five pieces of content that violated Facebook's policies would normally cause such pages to be taken down, but shielded sites were instead referred for further review.

One moderator explained: "If you start censoring too much, then people stop using the platform. It's all about money at the end of the day."

The suggestion that Facebook is seeking to profit from extremist or offensive material caused outrage. Leo Varadkar, the taoiseach, said there had been "a failure of self-regulation" and his government would examine bringing in a system of fines to ensure social-media companies "uphold basic standards of decency". The programme renewed calls for Ireland to establish a digital safety commissioner to police social media sites. Two years ago the Law Reform Commission recommended such a body, with powers to take court action against sites that failed to take down material that breached a statutory code of practice.

For David Ibsen, executive director of the Counter Extremism Project, a US non-profit group that aims to tackle extremist ideology, the only shocking thing about the Dispatches programme was that Facebook allowed an investigative journalist to be hired as a moderator. "This really shows the seriousness with which Facebook takes moderation," said Ibsen. "Imagine Facebook letting an investigative reporter into its engineering team. It wouldn't happen. If safety of users is really the No 1 concern for Facebook you have to ask, why is the work outsourced?" A 650-strong cohort of Facebook's 7,500 content reviewers worldwide are employed in Ireland through CPL. Google, whose YouTube site is a leading platform for extremist videos, also outsources moderation in Ireland.

Earlier this year The Sunday Times reported complaints from former Google moderators in Dublin that they worked in "click-farm" conditions and felt pressurised to process thousands of cases without having time to review content. Google denies asking reviewers to do this. Sources among the outsourced workers for both internet giants say turnover of staff in Dublin is high, and the pay is in the region of (EURO)11.06 to (EURO)13.85 an hour.

Ibsen said Facebook, which reported a record $5bn ((EURO)4.3bn) profit for the first quarter of 2018 despite the Cambridge Analytica scandal, could afford to hire thousands of moderators, but he did not believe the web giant was serious about tackling extremist content. "I maintain that when Facebook announces policy changes, it's really just PR to get rid of the bad press," he said.

Ibsen cites the example of an Isis video known as "cubs of the caliphate" showing a young boy executing a teenager. Ibsen said the video, uploaded in 2015 and used as a recruitment tool, was still on Facebook three years later.

"We've been saying all along that the companies don't want to remove bad content as it's part of the business plan. But that contradicts what Mark Zuckerberg has been saying publicly. So sincerity from the top is not trickling down. Unless the moderators are empowered to aggressively remove this stuff, it's not going to make a difference."

Last year Varadkar ruled out a digital safety commissioner, saying the government would ask the internet companies "to do more to protect people". Although Denis Naughten, the communications minister, said in January he would push ahead with the idea, no commitment was contained in the government's recent action plan for online safety.

Fiona Jennings, policy co-ordinator for the children's charity ISPCC, said it was "very disappointed" with the government's attitude. "The safety commissioner plan is based on an Australian model that has been working well. It's clear that self-regulation is not working. The fact that Facebook is keeping material online that identifies minors being abused is not acceptable."

The Law Reform Commission consulted children's and women's groups. A common gripe was that those who complained to gardai about online harassment were told by gardai there was "nothing they could do". Teenagers complained that the reporting systems on social-media sites were "not effective".

Ronan Lupton, a barrister who was a member of the internet content advisory group which reported to government in 2014, said none of its recommendations had been implemented. "Facebook is not breaking the law," said Lupton. "What they are doing is not applying community or internal standards the way they should. That could give rise to a liability, but it hasn't to date."

Lupton said he believed a designated minister for the internet would make more impact than a "siloed, weak digital safety commissioner". He said European law needed reform before a commissioner would have real teeth. EU laws, including the ecommerce directive that limits the liability of services that act as "mere conduits" of information, must be changed before social media outfits can be fined for not taking down material.

"We don't need a toothless quango," said Lupton. "What is the point in appointing a commissioner if they have no real power but to give a slap on the wrist? But if you bring in draconian laws, they will conflict with European law."

Facebook has insisted any suggestion it relies on extremist or offensive material to generate income is wrong. It says the vast majority of its 2bn users do not share offensive material but visit Facebook for "a safe, secure experience to share content with their family and friends". It has accepted that the trainers at CPL made mistakes and some of the material they had said was acceptable actually contravened its community standards. The training staff are being retrained. It has also announced that moderators will have the power to suspend accounts when they suspect users are under 13.

Andy Way still feels he made the right decision to quit Facebook in 2015. "It was a sacrifice not keeping in touch with old school friends but I'm glad I'm off. I probably wasted too much time on it," he said. "I've not been tempted to go back once."

Any policy changes are really just PR to get rid of the bad press

urn:contentItem:5RXX-S6W1-F125-111H-00000-00Big tech's dirty little secret is that its business model is unethical - it's time to hold Facebook and others accountable2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:23:13ZLexisNexisDIANE FRANCISBig tech's dirty little secret is that its business model is unethical - it's time to hold Facebookand others accountable

The dirty little secret about Facebook Inc., Alphabet Inc.and other tech companies is that their business model is unethical - it is a combination of espionage and propaganda.

This week the "data misuse" scandal, involving allegations that a third party obtained 50 million Facebookusers to influence the 2016 election, underscores this description and reveals the extent of the problem. Facebooksaid it did not know about or gave permission to do this.

But the bigger story is that Facebookand others should be held accountable for how they treat our data, never mind rogue third parties.

Interestingly, the centre of this week's scandal is a Canadian whistleblower, Christopher Wylie from B.C., who described how data was used by Cambridge Analytica, to create a psychological tool for Steve Bannon and the Trump campaign to "explore mental vulnerabilities of people" and to take "fake news to the next level."

"It was a grossly unethical experiment because you are playing with an entire country, the psychology of an entire country, without their consent or awareness."

But the phrase "consent and awareness" is key to understanding the bigger story here. For years, Facebook, Google and others have collected data from users by spying to determine their opinions, movements, friends, biases, and personality traits and then selling this info to advertisers, parties or others.

Behind Facebook's baby step fixes: Defending its ad business( http://business.financialpost.com/pmn/business-pmn/behind-facebooks-baby-step-fixes-defending-its-ad-business )

'This isn't going to cut it': Mark Zuckerberg's response to Facebookdata scandal fails to quell critics( http://business.financialpost.com/technology/personal-tech/this-isnt-going-to-cut-it-mark-zuckerbergs-response-to-facebook-data-scandal-fails-to-quell-critics )

For instance, Facebookknows, among its 2 billion users, who has depression, pimples or is racist, supremacist, or angry. This, plus analytics, is valuable to intermediaries and "advertisers" who target users to sell medicines, ideologies, assault rifles or demagogues.

The current revelations have shaken up the industry and stock market, forcing Facebookfounder Mark Zuckerberg into making public apologies and pledges to protect private data.

But his business model does not protect private data and sells it for enormous profits. The excuse, however, is that users get free services in return for signing away permission for them to collect and sell their data.

Such blanket permission should not be allowed because everyone's data is for sale, and passes through many hands, ending up with Russians and other unscrupulous parties.

Frankly, blanket permission is a joke, and buried in lengthy, incomprehensible Terms of Service contracts that must be clicked by users before getting Facebook, Twitter, Google, and other services.

Nobody reads them.

The danger of their business model was set out eloquently in a 2013 book by computer scientist Jaron Lanier called "Who Owns the Future?". He said concentration of power would grow to unacceptable proportions and recommended that tech companies must inform users about who is using their data and then make micro-payments to them. He described Facebookand the others as "spy agencies" and would lead to Big Brother behaviour and control over the economy, society and democracy.

The solutions are not difficult: Ideally, the model should be scrapped and tech companies should keep their paws off everyone's data and simply charge users for their search and social media usage.

But until that happens, users - not Facebookor other technology companies - will remain the victims of "data misuse" and exploitation without compensation.

Some governments in Europe have put in place legislation to prevent data collection and resale without permission of users. This is long overdue and the U.S. and Canada, or their courts, must act to stop abuses immediately.

Still others in the U.S. believe the tech companies may have already abrogated regulations.

This week, a U.S. Federal Trade Commission official said: "Consumers need stronger protections such as comprehensive data security and privacy laws, transparency and accountability for data brokers, and rights to and control over their data."
